title: Vietnam apparel industry calls for lower minimum wage
text:
Font size Email Print 
A 12.4% national minimum wage increase has been recommended 
Vietnam's textile and apparel industry is calling for a lower minimum wage to be set after a consensus was reached for a 12.4% increase to take effect from January 2016. 
In the third meeting of the National Wage Council today (3 September), a unanimous decision was reached between employers, trade unions and the Government for an increase of between VND250,000 and VND400,000 (US$11-$17.5), across the country, dependent on the area, according to the International Labour Organization (ILO). 
The move follows months of talks, and the new rate was agreed with 14 out of 15 votes in support of the increase. At present, the minimum wage is between VND2.15m and VND3.1m per month. 
A spokesperson for the ILO in Vietnam said the wage will now be recommended to the Prime Minister and the Chamber of Commerce and Industry of Vietnam to sign off. 
The country's textile and apparel industry, however, has voiced concerns over the agreed rate, with the Vietnam Textile and Apparel Association calling for a lower increase of 6-7% given the “labour intensity” of the sector, which employs around 2.5m people. 
The export turnover of the sector reached around US$24bn in 2014 and is expected to reach $27.5bn for fiscal 2015. 
The Association argues that a 10% rise will increase total labour costs by over $23.2m, while insurance premiums will go up by $8.7m, and union fees by $530m, thereby reducing corporate profits. 
Figures from the group show that from 2010 to the present day, the minimum wage has increased from 2.15 to 2.3 times for FDI; from 2.95 to 3.16 times for domestic firms, and employer insurance from 18% in 2010 to 22% in 2014. 
The Association has written to the country's Prime Minister recommending that the Government reduces the percentage of insurance payments, and reduces funding for trade unions by 10%, giving businesses more power to look after workers with regard to housing support and childcare, for example. 
A number of textile associations have voiced support for the Textile and Apparel Association, with Tran Phuong, chairman of the Phu Tho Textile and Garment Association, saying that wage growth should be "voluntary" so businesses don't lose competitiveness and an ability to reinvest.
